text:
Consider the following situation:

Everything is a donkey, or a human, or a monkey (exclusively), and there's at least one of each. Lewis saw Lewis. Every donkey chased every donkey that chased it. Only humans are hungry and every human is happy. Not all donkeys chased Alfred just in case no donkeys chased Alfred. If a human chased Lewis, then Hazel didn't chase Hazel only if every monkey saw Hazel.

Which, if any, of the following statements must be true in this situation?

1. No donkeys chased every donkey.
2. Every donkey chased every donkey.
3. A donkey chased every donkey.
4. A donkey chased every donkey that chased it.
5. Every donkey chased a donkey.
6. A donkey chased a donkey.

Consider the following situation:

Everything is a donkey, or a human, or a monkey (exclusively), and there's at least one of each. Alfred or Hazel will run. Only donkeys will run. Every monkey saw Hazel. If Alfred will run, then every monkey is asleep only if every human saw Hazel.

Which, if any, of the following statements must be true in this situation?

1. Alfred will run.
2. A donkey will run.
3. Not all donkeys will run.
4. Alfred and Hazel will run.
5. Every donkey will run.
6. No donkeys will run.

Consider the following situation:

Everything is a donkey, or a human, or a monkey (exclusively), and there's at least one of each. A donkey saw every donkey. No donkeys saw Lewis and no donkeys saw Hazel. A human saw Alfred just in case every monkey chased Hazel.

Which, if any, of the following statements must be true in this situation?

1. Lewis is a donkey.
2. Hazel is a donkey.
3. Lewis isn't a donkey.
4. Alfred isn't a donkey.
5. Alfred is a donkey.

Consider the following situation:

Everything is a donkey, or a human, or a monkey (exclusively), and there's at least one of each. A donkey chased a donkey that chased a monkey. Lewis saw every human. No donkeys saw Lewis but it is not the case that Lewis isn't a donkey. Not all monkeys kicked Lewis and no donkeys saw Hazel. A donkey kicked Lewis only if no donkeys chased Alfred.

Which, if any, of the following statements must be true in this situation?

1. Hazel is a donkey.
2. Alfred isn't a donkey.
3. Lewis isn't a donkey.
4. Alfred is a donkey.
5. Lewis isn't a human.
6. Lewis is a human.

Consider the following situation:

Everything is a donkey, or a human, or a monkey (exclusively), and there's at least one of each. Lewis saw Hazel. Not all donkeys kicked Hazel. A monkey chased Alfred and every monkey saw Alfred.

Which, if any, of the following statements must be true in this situation?

1. If Alfred doesn't see Lewis, then every monkey chased Hazel only if every monkey saw Lewis.
2. A monkey chased Alfred and Lewis doesn't see Hazel.
3. Alfred didn't chase Hazel just in case no monkeys saw Lewis.
4. Every monkey chased Alfred but it is not the case that Lewis doesn't see Hazel.
5. Every monkey chased Alfred and Lewis doesn't see Hazel.
6. A monkey chased Alfred but it is not the case that Lewis doesn't see Hazel.
